title: Do you have examples of comical, yet legitimate, scientific experiments? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ohhhh I have one that’s cute. GE nuclear reactors are radioactive from the boiler vessel to the turbine/generator. As you can understand, this is a very important fact to know. OK…. as the steam hits the turbines from high to the low stages, the steam condenses and is directed to a holding tank. In that tank we have a level switch. When the water reaches a certain point, the switch turns on and the water is pumped back into the boiler reactor circulation system to become steam again. Now, this part of the system was not designated as safety related originally. That is a system that must work to allow a safe reactor shutdown in case of an emergency. Because it wasn’t safety related, no one was monitoring failure reports on that switch. Once the system became safety related, the reports become very very important. It turned out that this switch would fail to operate on average of ten days. Every time it failed, someone had to go to the switch and manually operate it to unstick it. Every switch did that. It got so bad, they actually tied a string from the switch to a catwalk up above and placed a video camera on it that can be viewed from the reactor control room. So every ten days, when it got stuck, someone would put on their suite and dose meters and go to the catwalk to pull the string to get the level switch to work again. Now that the condensation system is designated as safety related, that is no longer permissible. It had to be decided what was wrong and then come up with a solution. At this point you would wonder why they lived with it for so long. Well, in nuclear, you have a licence that is based on the FSAR. Final Safety Analysis Report. This baby establishes the engineering baseline of the nuclear reactor. You can’t change anything to something else without going for a full blown engineering review and design. The fear is that you may change the original design of the system by changing a small part. Change enough small parts over time, and the reactor is no longer the same reactor licensed. So because of the headaches this would cause, they decided to live with the problem. So when it went safety related, the problem became too much to ignore and that's when they called me in. My job was to analyse faults on parts or system to figure out what went wrong outside of the normal wear and tear of it, and then come up with a solution for all 8 nuclear power stations in the company. Sometimes it’s critical and I have 3 days to do it and report to the NRC or else we shut down the entire reactor. That means we’re not producing electricity and that means no revenue. Not a good thing. So I get the switch sent to my lab. And this is it.  This baby is a Mercoid 123 apartment boiler water level control switch. It made sure that there was water in the boiler that supplied heat to the apartment building. I used to sell it when I first graduated from college when I was a sales engineer. It is the most simplest, stupidest, ugliest and most unreliable switch I ever saw. I avoided selling it. And this is the switch that was sent to my lab. I did an “autopsy” on it and a new switch from stores. With a video camera to record it. Noted all the parameters critical to operation. Investigated the original design of the part against the current design…. the whole nine yards…. I even used an electron microscope and found out that someone was sticking grease into it. That was not good. That changed the design. I wrote my report. Do you know what I found out? The manual tells the operator that the building engineer (caretaker) has to manually operate the switch every morning to ensure reliable operation for the rest of the day. This has to be done every morning. Along with that, a warning label is fixed to the switch when it’s shipped to the plant. YOU MUST MANUALLY OPERATE SWITCH ONCE A DAY FOR RELIABLE OPERATION. This was exactly what the station was doing… only after it failed. The solution: The switch must be operated once a day per manufacturer’s operating instructions. That was it. The station wouldn’t buy it. Why is the switch failing? My argument was that the switch was not failing. It was operating within its designed operation parameters. Regardless of what is going wrong we are not the engineering authority of the switch and we cannot make any changes to it without violating the FSAR. The switch works. Just pull the string every morning. But no, they wanted to know what was wrong. This went back and forth for a couple of days. It went like this: Why is the switch failing? Did you manually operate the switch that morning? No. That’s why it failed. But why is it failing? It doesn’t matter why. You didn’t follow instructions. Did you manually operate the switch? No. That’s why it failed. Finally someone at the station stepped in and agreed with me. Then we held meetings to determine what switch would best do the job as a candidate for the full blown engineering review and design that should have been done years ago. This, my friend, is how we keep nuclear reactors running in the States.

Scientists at NYU built a robot to simulate a predatory fish. It looked like this:  Note the plastic googly eyes, which I feel were necessary for verisimilitude. (They also built a heron, but I find that less comical.) They used this terror to scare the shit out of zebrafish, a standard model organism. Then they got the zebrafish drunk. Yes, really. Now, there’s all a really good explanation for this. Zebrafish teeny tiny fish that are transparent as embryos; they’re used to study everything. My lab shares the floor with folks who use them to study kidney disease. The group at NYU was studying nervous system responses to threatening stimuli and to a zebrafish that robot is pretty damn threatening. Standard methods of terrifying zebrafish would include showing videos of predatory fish, having predatory fish in an adjacent tank or… well, I’ll save the other standard method for later on in this answer. But the robot is better because the researchers could directly control the stimulus and because it could be directly threatening to their test subjects–right next to them!–without eating them. They got the zebrafish drunk to compare responses to the robo-predator in drunk and sober zebrafish. As expected, the drunk fish were less responsive; apparently alcohol reduces anxiety in fish too. There’s no indication on whether any of the zebrafish were teetotalers who chose not to partake. A better write-up of this research was done by Elizabeth Preston at Inkfish when the paper was published. Cianca, Valentina, Tiziana Bartolini, Maurizio Porfiri, and Simone Macrì. 2013. “A Robotics-Based Behavioral Paradigm to Measure Anxiety-Related Responses in Zebrafish.” PLoS ONE 8 (7). doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0069661.

Some students at MIT decided to conduct a joke study on the effects of tin foil hats since the basic theory is that tin foil hats either: keep the government from reading your mind; orkeep the government from broadcasting messages directly into your mind.Complete joke, right? Well, they found out that a certain configuration of a tin foil hat actually INCREASES the effectiveness of a range of frequencies currently held in reserve for governmental use. So, the conclusion was that if you were a conspiracy theorist, the use of tin foil hats was created by the government, in a fit of reverse psychology, to broadcast messages directly into your mind. There is another joke study from the University of Minnesota about trees falling in the woods do they make a sound, but I cannot find it.

Here is a good one: Coffee stains It is especially good because it sounds like a comical, stupid idea for science. In fact, the physics is important in any number of industrial processes. As an example, consider how ink is distributed on the paper as the droplets from your ink jet printer dry. There is also this: Shrimp on a treadmill? Pacific University professor defends his research, excoriates Republican critics Every few years some Congress critter will make a stink about some silly sounding study that, in fact, turns out to be really important.

In the 1950’s some scientists decided to prank the government grant system by applying for funding for an experiment they considered so outlandish that it defied imagination that it could ever be approved. What they proposed doing was training planaria to negotiate a maze, then grinding them up and feeding them to planaria that had never been exposed to the maze to see if that would make the dumb planaria smart with respect to being able to run the maze. Amazingly they got the grant and so had to run the experiment and to everyone’s surprise it worked. The ability of planarian worms to run a maze more successfully after being fed the remains of a successful worm

I’ve got two favorites: Students at Rice University demonstrated that bread really does fall butter-side down when dropped from the height of a table [~2000s].A study published anonymously [in Nature, I think, late 1960s] that investigated the correlation between frequency of sexual relations and growth of facial hair. The author of the study concluded by saying that as s/he would be married soon, s/he anticipated that the logistics of further investigation would soon become simpler. In the story I heard about it, the reviewer took issue with the final statement.

I present you a very important medical experiment performed in Singapore, nearly ten years ago: The Tao of bao: a randomised controlled trial examining the effect of steamed bun consumption on night-call inpatient course and mortality. Basically the steamed bun is called “bao” in Chinese languages, which sounds uncannily like the words for “shroud” or “body bag”, leading to a common superstition that eating steamed buns during one’s medical duties - particularly at night - would result in bad luck and possibly even death for one’s patients. So this being Singapore, some smart-alec decided to test whether it was true. The results? Your doctor eating steamed buns won't kill you, it turns out, but the stress and fatigue of being on shift just about might. Science!

My story is short. In an astrophysics conference in 1983, we were presented with a scatter plot of experimental results on the size of the core of Jupiter. There was a small cloud of points, very narrowly centered on one value of the radius. But there was another point, way off, that kept re-appearing on all plots, causing the re-scaling of the plots. Just to be able to see all points, the small cloud of points had to be squashed. “What about the point way up, is that an error, a typo, I mean, it’s so way off”, asked a physicist. “What is it? “Soviet measurement”.

I got my MS doing research for the Army. I had to measure how torn up the ground got when tanks versus APCs versus Hummers ran it over dozens of times. Four Army bases and god knows how much cash later, the startling conclusion was that the larger, heavier vehicles caused more damage.
Imagine writing the grant for this study that had a central claim that eating boogers is good for you: Whoa, whoa, whoa wait…Eating Boogers Could Be Good For You?

How about internet via carrier pigeons? There’s an RFC <IP over Avian Carriers with Quality of Service> (for an upgraded spec!) It has been implemented, <IP over Avian Carriers - Wikipedia> There is some mention of IPv6 but I have no experience of this being implemented.
Improbable Research this will provide you with annual examples.

Here’s a nice little study on the ‘half-life’ of spoons in the tea rooms of the Burnet Institute: The case of the disappearing teaspoons: longitudinal cohort study of the displacement of teaspoons in an Australian research institute
You can find more than you’ll ever need. Start here : List of Ig Nobel Prize winners - Wikipedia
